title: 109_hr1769
content: The Act may be cited as the "September 11th Heroes Memorial Park Act". On September 11, 2001, terrorists hijacked 4 civilian aircraft, crashing 2 into the World Trade Center towers in New York City, causing their destruction. This was the deadliest terrorist attack in the United States, claiming over 3,000 lives, with 2,797 deaths in New York City. Debris from the towers was taken to a landfill on Staten Island for cleanup and investigation, where over 1,000 people worked around the clock for 10 months. Approximately 20 percent of victim remains and over 54,000 personal items were recovered at the Staten Island landfill, providing some peace to families of the 306 identified World Trade Center victims. The cleanup and recovery operations at the Staten Island landfill concluded on July 15, 2002, providing closure to families of the 306 identified World Trade Center victims. The site is being considered for designation as a unit of the National Park System to appropriately commemorate those lost. The purposes of this Act are to establish a national memorial at the site of the Fresh Kills Landfill on Staten Island, New York, to honor those lost at the World Trade Center on September 11, 2001. It also includes the formation of a memorial advisory commission to plan and construct the memorial. Established a memorial at the Staten Island recovery site to honor those lost at the World Trade Center on September 11, 2001. An advisory commission will also be formed. The "September 11th Heroes Memorial Park Advisory Commission" is established with 15 members, including representatives from the National Park Service, Secretary of the Interior, Congress, mayor of New York City, and governor of New York. Members serve for the life of the Commission and select their own Chair. The Commission members select the Chair, vacancies are filled in the same manner as the original appointment, meetings are called by the Chairperson or majority, must meet quarterly, and agendas are published. A majority of members constitutes a quorum, members serve without compensation but may be reimbursed for expenses. The Commission is responsible for submitting a report with recommendations for a permanent memorial, advising on boundaries and management plans, coordinating with relevant parties, and ensuring adequate federal funding for long-term operation and maintenance of the memorial. The Commission has the power to make expenditures, accept gifts, hold hearings, enter contracts, and delegate tasks to carry out the Act for the memorial. The Commission can delegate duties to National Park Service staff and will terminate upon completion of the memorial. SEC. 5. DUTIES OF THE SECRETARY. The Secretary of the Interior is authorized to provide assistance to the Commission in various ways, including advice on collections, storage, and archives, conducting oral history interviews, participating in planning efforts for the memorial, providing design assistance for exhibits, and supporting design and construction activities. Staff assistance and support are also provided, along with participation in formulating plans for the design. The Commission is authorized to participate in the design and construction of the September 11th heroes memorial, acquire land for the site, and administer it as a unit of the National Park Service.
